title-group.article-title: Thermoplastic vulcanizates based on compatibilized polyurethane and silicone rubber blend

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China

author-notes.corresp: Cai-Hong Lei, Faculty of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China Email: LCH528@gdut.edu.cn

abstract.p: The polyurethane (PU)/silicone rubber dynamic vulcanizated elastomer was prepared using Pt catalyst and organohydrido silicone compound as cross-linking agent. The effect of segmented PU modified by hydroxyalkyl functional polydimethylsiloxane (Si–PU) as a compatibilizer was investigated. It is found that simple blend shows co-continuous structure and worse mechanical properties. After dynamic vulcanization, the elongation at break improved to 745.8% when the contents of catalyst and cross-linking agent are 0.12 phr and 1.65 phr, respectively. The introduction of Si–PU in 4.5 phr further improves the value to 942.6% and the sizes of cross-linked rubber dispersed in the continuous PU matrix are less than 8 μm. Si–PU copolymer shows better compatibilization effect.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyurethane (PU) is an important class of thermoplastic material which has found utility in a variety of commercial applications. There is still a need to prepare PU compounds that can retain physical properties after exposure to heat (for example at 120–150°C) for extended periods of time. Silicone rubber is a high-performance material having good thermal and oxidative stability, low glass transition temperature and resistance to ultraviolet radiation. However, it exhibits rather poor mechanical properties. It is possible to obtain better properties by compounding PU and silicone rubber through dynamic vulcanization method.

It is well known that the physical properties of thermoplastic vulcanizates (TPVs) depend strongly on the blend composition, the cross-link density of the rubber phase and the rubber dispersion and particle size. 1
–9 The strong dependence of the tensile properties on the rubber particle size was demonstrated by Coran and Duin for TPVs based on polypropylene (PP) and ethylene–propylene–diene (EPDM) rubber. 1
–5 Both the elongation at break and the tensile strength were increased by a factor of five by decreasing the rubber particle size from 70 μm to 1 μm. The sizes of the elastomer can be varied by the compatibility of the components. The interfacial tension between the components should be relatively low to acquire a good and fine dispersion of the rubber phase. For the blends with high interfacial tension, the compatibilizer can decrease the interfacial tension and the sizes of rubber phase. Papke and Karger-Kocsis 9 have proved that the compatibilizer (glycidyl methacrylate-grafted rubber) can improve the compatibility and the sizes in poly(ethylene terephthalate) and various rubber TPV.

Due to the difference in the molecular structure between PU and silicone rubber, the blend is immiscible. For this system, to obtain good interfacial adhesion and to reduce the interfacial tension, the compatibilization is necessary. Hu et al. 10 found that the addition of dimethyl silicone oil to the PU/Si-rubber hybrid system resulted in the decrease in the diameter of PU agglomerates and the distribution of the PU agglomerates became more uniform. Maity and Khatua 11 used vinyl triacetoxy silane-grafted silicone rubber to improve the compatibility and physical properties of PU/silicone rubber blends, and it was found that the physical properties such as hardness, modulus and tensile strength increased compared to the pure blend. However, up to now, except some patents mentioning the preparation of PU/silicone rubber TPV, 12 no work reported the structure and properties of this kind of TPV. Even in those patents, the compatibility of this system is not mentioned.

Specialty PUs based on polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) soft segments have been extensively studied during the last 25 years. 13
–21 PDMS-based PUs have unique combination of properties, which mainly stems from the characteristics of the PDMS soft segments. These include extremely low glass transition temperatures of around −120°C, good oxidative and thermal stability, water repellency, physiological inertness and high gas permeability. Wang and Ji 17 prepared segmented PUs derived from hydroxyl terminated polytetramethylene oxide soft segment, 4,4′-methylene diphenyl diisocyanate, 1,4-butanediol (BDO) and secondary aminoalkyl functional PDMS oligomer via solution polymerization. Stanciu et al. 18 reported that due to the thermodynamical incompatibility of the hard and soft segments, the copolymers should be of two-phase systems. They consisted of hard segments dispersed in a continuous or semicontinuous elastomeric soft phase.

In this article, the PU/silicone rubber TPV was prepared using Pt as the catalyst and organohydrido silicone compound as the cross-linking agent. The relationship between structure and mechanical properties was discussed. The influence of PDMS-modified PU copolymer on its compatibility and properties was investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PU with a hardness of 90 A is supplied by Kingfa Co., China. Vinylsiloxane rubber (0.15 wt% vinyl; VSR), chloroplatinic acid, divinyltetramethyldisiloxane, stannous octoate, organohydrido silicone compound (1 wt% H–Si) and a hydroxyalkyl functional PDMS (M n = 1000 g/mol) are purchased from JUCHEN Co., China. 4,4′-Methylene diphenylene diisocyanate (MDI; Bayer, Germany), BDO (Kermel, Tianjin, China) and polyethylene glycol (PEG-2000; Guanghua Chemical Factory, China) are vacuum distilled before use. Dimethyl acetamide (DMAc), tetrahydrofuran (THF), tetrachloromethane and methanol are all of reagent grades and used without further purification.

sec.title: Preparation of Pt catalytic agent
sec.p: Chloroplatinic acid and divinyltetramethyldisiloxane were decanted into a three-necked flask. The vessel was evacuated by nitrogen and the system was heated to 120°C. The reaction runs for 1 h after which the solution was washed by distilled water until pH = 7. Then the reactive sample was dried by calcium chloride and collected in brown glass.

sec.title: Preparation of PDMS-modified PU copolymer (Si–PU)
sec.p: Similar to the method used by Wang and Ji, 17 the Si–PU copolymer was synthesized. The reaction was conducted in a four-neck round bottom flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, nitrogen inlet and condense pipe. PEG, MDI, BDO and PDMS were dissolved in DMAc/THF (1:1) to afford a 40 wt% solution. The solution was heated to 60°C and then the reaction was catalyzed by 0.4 mol% of stannous octoate for 0.5 h. The viscous solution was maintained for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the copolymer was precipitated into methanol solution, filtered and dried in a vacuum oven at 50°C for 24 h.

sec.title: Preparation of PU/VSR binary blend and TPV
sec.p: Prior to mixing, PU was dried for 2 h at 105°C. A Haake Rheomix 600 mixer (Thermo Electron Corporation, Germany) was used to prepare PU/VSR binary blend and TPV. The mixing temperature and rotor speed were held constant at 190°C and 70 r/min for all runs. The PU/VSR blend ratio was 45:55. During the preparation of TPV, PU was first added into the mixer and then VSR was introduced. At point (a) in Figure 1, the organohydrido silicone compound was added and finally at point (b) the Pt catalyst was introduced. Then, the reaction lasted for 5 min and was stopped. In our previous study, 22 it has been found that to achieve better mechanical properties for PU/VSR TPV, the curing time of 5 min is best.

caption.p: Torque–time curve during the preparation of TPV in Haake mixer. TPV: thermoplastic vulcanizate.

sec.title: Characterization of Si–PU copolymer
sec.p: The Si–PU copolymer was first purified by tetrachloromethane to remove unreactive PDMS. Then, the purified sample was pressed into 100 μm films, by compressing 0.1–0.2 g sample between Telflon-covered aluminum sheet under 1 MPa pressure at ambient temperature for 30 s. The pressed film was submitted to infrared analysis in a Perkin Elmer PE 1600 spectrophotometer with the resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans per spectrum. The element content of Si–PU was measured by elemental analyzer which was connected to S-3400NQ10 scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) measurements, in THF, were conducted on a Viscotek 270max apparatus from Malvern Instruments China (differential refraction device detector, calibration versus polystyrene standard).

sec.title: Characterization of PU/VSR binary blend and TPV
sec.p:
Tensile tests were carried out according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) D412-98 on dumbbell-shaped specimens using a universal tensile testing machine (KQL, China) at a constant strain speed of 500 mm/min. Tear strength was measured according to ASTM D624-81 using unpicked 90° angle test piece. Hardness measurements were carried out using Shore A Durometers (Zwick model 3114 instrument) according to ASTM D 2240-81. The compression set was measured on cylindrical samples with a diameter of 13 mm and a thickness of 6 mm at 25% compressive deformation for 24 h at 150°C and a relaxation time of 30 min at room temperature, according to ASTM D395. sec.title: Preparation and properties of PU/VSR TPV
sec.p: First, PU/VSR TPV without compatibilizer is prepared using different contents of cross-linking agent and catalyst. VSR can be vulcanized by different curatives such as peroxide and organohydrido silicon compound (Si–H). 23,24 With respect to peroxide, the Si–H can only react with the vinyl part in silicone rubber with the help of Pt catalyst. The cross-linking mechanism is as follows.

Regarding the Pt catalyst, Tang et al. 24 has compared the efficiency of different catalysts for VSR and proved that chloroplatinic acid–divinyltetramethyldisiloxane complex showed highest catalytic ability. Hence, in our experiments, Si–H and chloroplatinic acid–divinyltetramethyldisiloxane complex are used to prepare PU/VSR TPV.

Table 1 shows the mechanical properties of prepared TPV with different contents of catalyst and cross-linking agent. The tensile strength and elongation at break for binary blend are only 0.91 MPa and 115.3%, respectively. With the increase in the contents of cross-linking agent and catalyst, the mechanical properties of prepared TPV increased initially and then decreased. When the content of cross-linking agent is 1.65 phr, the tensile strength is 12.4 MPa. The gel fraction increases from 80.0% to 94.5% with the increase in the contents of the cross-linking agent from 0.55 phr to 1.65 phr. After that, the gel fraction does not change much, but unnecessary cross-linking agent induces the decrease in mechanical properties. When the Pt catalyst content is 0.12 phr and the cross-linking agent content is 1.65 phr, the system shows best properties. Compared with that of simple blend, the tensile strength and elongation at break are improved by 1273% and 546%, respectively.

sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the SEM of samples before and after dynamic vulcanization. The dark area represents PU phase. It can be seen that before dynamic vulcanization, the system shows co-continuous structure and there are some cracks on the surface, indicating low interfacial adhesion between PU and VSR. The structure proves worse mechanical properties for binary blend. Figure 2 (b, c and d), samples after dynamic vulcanization, shows the morphology of cross-linked rubber dispersed in the continuous PU phase. The phase conversion is finished during dynamic vulcanization, similar to many results given in PP/EPDM system. 1
–6 When the catalyst content is 0.04 phr, some cracks on the surface are still observed. Here, lower catalytic ability cannot induce enough cross-linking of silicone rubber in Haake mixer. Under the content of 0.12 phr and 0.16 phr, the cross-linked VSR particles are uniformly dispersed in the continuous PU phase and no cracks can be observed, especially under the content of 0.16 phr. Compared with that before vulcanization, the sizes of rubber phase are decreased pronouncedly. Only some cross-linked VSR particles are larger than 10 μm. The SEM results explain the change in mechanical property under different contents of Pt catalyst (Table 1). It can be seen that dynamic vulcanization results in better interfacial adhesion between PU and VSR.

caption.p: SEM of samples before (a) and after dynamic vulcanization with different contents of catalyst: (b) 0.04 phr, (c) 0.12 phr and (d) 0.16 phr. SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the TG curve of PU/VSR TPV. The curve of TPV is sitting between PU and VSR. Compared with pure PU, the onset decomposition temperature does not change much. But it is apparent that the decomposition rate of TPV is slower than that of pure PU. The introduction of VSR into TPU improves its thermal resistant behavior.

caption.p: TG curves of pure PU (1), pure VSR (3) and PU/VSR TPV (2). PU: polyurethane; TG: thermogravimetry; TPV: thermoplastic vulcanizates; VSR: vinylsiloxane rubber.

sec.title: Characterization of PDMS-modified PU copolymer (Si–PU)
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy curve of synthesized Si–PU copolymer. No absorption bands can be observed around 2000 cm−1, indicating that isocyanate in MDI has been completely reacted. The absorption bands around 3448 cm−1 (N–H stretching) and 1630 cm−1 (H-bonded urea C=O stretching) are assigned to the urea linkage. The peak at 1095 cm−1 is due to the contribution of C–O–C stretching. The peaks at 1264 cm−1 (Si–CH3), 1020 cm−1 (Si–O–Si stretching), 804 cm−1 (CH3 rocking) are assigned to the PDMS in the copolymer. Figure 5 shows the results of elemental analysis. The calculated weight percentage of C, H, Si elements in Si–PU copolymer is 58.1%, 36.1% and 5.80%, respectively. It is confirmed that PDMS is successfully copolymerized onto the PU backbone. Figure 6 shows the GPC curve of Si–PU copolymer. Based on polystyrene standard calibration curve, the calculated number − average molecular weight (Mn) is 19,003 and the polydispersity (Mw/Mn value) is 1.385.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of synthesized Si–PU copolymer. FTIR: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; PU: polyurethane; Si: silicone.
Elemental analysis of synthesized Si–PU copolymer. PU: polyurethane; Si: silicone.
GPC curve of synthesized Si–PU copolymer. GPC: gel permeation chromatography; PU: polyurethane; Si: silicone.

sec.title: Effect of Si–PU copolymer on the properties of PU/VSR TPV
sec.p: Table 2 lists the properties of TPV with different contents of Si–PU copolymer. With the increase in the content of Si–PU copolymer, the tensile strength and elongation at break also increase. Especially, the elongation at break is improved by 26.7% when the Si–PU copolymer content is 4.5–6 phr. Another apparent change is the compression set. It is decreased by 24%.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of TPV with different contents of Si–PU copolymer

fn.p: PU: polyurethane; Si: silicone; TPV: thermoplastic vulcanizate.

sec.p:
Figure 7 shows the SEM of samples after dynamic vulcanization with Si–PU copolymer content of 4.5 phr. Compared with that of TPV without compatibilizer (Figure 2(c)), the dispersion of cross-linked VSR rubber becomes better and some larger particles existing in the system without compatibilizer disappear. The size of cross-linked VSR particles is less than 8 μm. The decrease in the size of cross-linked rubber results in better mechanical properties, which is in agreement with those conclusions drawn by Coran et al. in PP/EPDM systems. 1

It is seen that at constant shear rate and viscosity ratio, the sizes can be reduced by reducing the interfacial tension. For PU/VSR blend, the increase in mechanical property (Table 2) and the decrease in the size of the cross-linked rubber (Figure 7) indicate that the interfacial interaction between VSR and PU is increased by the introduction of Si–PU copolymer. In Si–PU copolymer, the PDMS part shows affinity to VSR rubber, while the PU part is compatible with the PU matrix in TPV. Yilgor et al. has proved that the incorporation of PDMS in the PU chains enhances the microphase separation between hard and soft segments. 13
–
16 In addition, there exists a phase separation between the PEG and PDMS chains inside the soft blocks, due to their incompatibility. 15 It is this kind of structure that makes the Si–PU copolymer sitting at the interphase between PU and VSR resulting in better compatibility effect. Therefore, Si–PU copolymer can act as a typical compatibilizer of block copolymer.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PU/VSR TPV with cross-linked rubber dispersed in the continuous PU phase is successfully prepared using Pt catalyst and Si–H cross-linking agent. Compared with that of the simple blend, the mechanical properties of TPV are improved pronouncedly. The properties can be affected by the content of the cross-linking agent, catalytic agent and compatibilizer. The introduction of Si–PU copolymer as a compatibilizer successfully improves the dispersion of cross-linked VSR in the continuous PU matrix. The mechanical property is best with 1.65 phr of cross-linking agent, 0.12 phr of catalytic agent and 4.5 phr of Si–PU copolymer.
